section.title: all files are case sensitive
section.para: Linux is case sensitivecase sensitive, this means that FILE1 is different from file1, and /etc/hosts is different from /etc/Hosts (the latter one does not exist on a typical Linux computer).
This screenshot points to the difference between two files, one with uppercase W, the other with lowercase w.
section.screen: paul@laika:~/Linux$ ls winter.txt Winter.txt paul@laika:~/Linux$ cat winter.txt It is cold. paul@laika:~/Linux$ cat Winter.txt It is very cold!

section.title: everything is a file
section.para: A directory is a special kind of file, but it is still a file. Even a terminal window or a hard disk are represented somewhere in de file system hierarchy by a file. It will become clear troughout this course that everything on Linux is a file.

section.title: / (the root directory)
section.para: All Linux systems have a directory structure that starts at the root directoryroot directory. The root directory is represented by a slash, like this: // . Everything that exists on your linux system can be found below this root directory. Let's take a brief look at the contents of the root directory.
section.screen: [paul@RHELv4u3 ~]$ ls / bin dev home media mnt proc sbin srv tftpboot usr boot etc lib misc opt root selinux sys tmp var [paul@RHELv4u3 ~]$

section.title: man hier
section.para: There are some differences between Linux distributions. For help about your machine, enter man hierman hier to find information about the file system hierarchy. This manual will explain the directory structure on your computer.

section.title: filesystem hierarchy standard
section.para: Many Linux distributions (partly) follow the Filesystem Hierarchy StandardFilesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS). Maybe the FHS will make more Unix/Linux file system trees unite in the future. The FHSFHS is available online at http://www.pathname.com/fhs/http://www.pathname.com/fhs/ where we read: "The filesystem hierarchy standard has been designed to be used by Unix distribution developers, package developers, and system implementors. However, it is primarily intended to be a reference and is not a tutorial on how to manage a Unix filesystem or directory hierarchy.".
